title: Lesson 1: Important Cells in Forensics
text:
Before diving into forensics, it’s best to have a foundational understanding of the common cell types found at crime scenes.


This lesson introduces a number of important cell types found in forensics including saliva, buccal, blood, and skin.

 Get Started

title: Review Quiz
text:
Test your knowledge of the important cell types used in forensic science. Select the best answer for each question and click “Check Answer” to see if you got it right.


Examine the microscope image below. What type of cells are shown in this forensic sample?





 Buccal epithelial cells from the inside of the cheek  Red blood cells from a blood sample  Skin cells from fingerprint evidence  Saliva cells from a drinking glass

Check Answer






Which forensic evidence sources commonly contain epithelial cells that can be analyzed for DNA?


 Cups, cigarettes, and bite marks  Only blood samples  Hair follicles exclusively

Check Answer






What is the primary purpose of studying different epithelial cell types in forensic science?


 To understand and compare physical attributes of cells from different body sources  To determine the age of evidence  To identify the time of death  To determine weapon types used

Check Answer






Why is saliva evidence especially useful in forensic investigations?


 It never degrades over time  It can link suspects to crimes or confirm identities  It only comes from criminals

Check Answer

title: Buccal Cells
text:
Buccal cells under microscope







Buccal cells under microscope






  Buccal cells, also known as cheek cells, are the epithelial cells that line the inside of a person's cheeks and mouth. They are easy to collect by gently swabbing the inner cheek with a cotton swab, which makes them one of the most common and non-invasive sources of DNA in forensic science.  

  Because buccal cells contain a complete set of an individual's genetic material, they are frequently used in criminal investigations, paternity testing, and medical research. Buccal swabs are especially valuable because they are painless to obtain, do not require blood or invasive procedures, and provide reliable DNA samples for identification.
  
    
      Watch Buccal Cells Video

title: Skin Cells
text:
Skin cells under microscope







Skin cells under microscope






  Skin cells are frequently left behind through touch and can serve as trace evidence in forensic investigations. 

  Even small amounts, known as "touch DNA," can provide genetic material for identification, helping link a suspect or victim to objects, locations, or other individuals involved in a case.
  
    
      Watch Skin Cells Video

title: Lesson 1 Objectives
text:
Students will be able to:



Understand and compare the physical attributes of epithelial cells derived from different body sources/source tissue


Identify key differences between epithelial cells


Identify and describe different cells

title: Saliva Cells
text:
Saliva cells under microscope







Saliva cells under microscope






  
    Saliva cells play a vital role in forensic science because they contain DNA that can be used to identify individuals.
  
  
    When saliva is left behind on objects such as cups, cigarettes, or bite marks, forensic experts can collect epithelial cells from the sample, extract the DNA, and compare it to known profiles.
  
  
    This makes saliva evidence especially useful in linking suspects to crimes or confirming identities in investigations.
  
  
    
      Watch Saliva Cells Video

title: Blood Cells
text:
Blood cells under microscope







Blood cells under microscope






  Blood cells are a key source of DNA in forensic science, making them crucial for identifying individuals and linking suspects to crime scenes. 

  Blood evidence can also provide information about blood type, patterns, and spatter, which helps investigators reconstruct events and determine how a crime occurred.
  
    
      Watch Blood Cells Video

title: Introduction to Cell Analysis
text:
In the context of biology, cell analysis refers to computational and statistical methods to attract data from images.


It involves image analysis techniques like:



Cell Finding (Segmentation) - Identifies each individual type of cell in the image.


Measuring Features (Extraction) - Measures the cell’s size, shape, etc.


Counting/Summarizing (Statistics) - Measures cell count, area, and etc.



In the last section of this lesson, you’ll get an interactive introduction to these techniques.
